author: S Sundar
text:
Despite a massive contraction of economies world over, devaluation of currencies, falling prices of commodities and China pumping its excess production at a subsidised rate into export market, Indian economy is growing at seven per cent, according to Union Minister of State for Commerce and Industry Nirmala Sitharaman.

Addressing a meeting on ‘Madurai Corporate Engagement’, organised by CII here on Friday, Ms. Sitharaman said that Prime Minister Narendra Modi was concerned about the global economic situation that was posing a challenge to Indian exporters. “Even yesterday, he reviewed the Indian trade, free trade agreements, preferential trade agreements,” she said.

The Centre had infused liquidity into the economy through increased public spending on infrastructure development such as highways, green field airports and improvement of brown field airports and creating industrial corridors and hubs to generate jobs and keep the economy buoyant.

She said that she had offered to extend Visakapattinam-Chennai industrial corridor till Thoothukudi while participating in the global investors’ meet in Chennai recently. Linking of Colachel and Thoothukudi sea ports would help trigger economic activities in south Tamil Nadu, she said.

Selection of 36 cities under Atal Mission for Rejuvenation and Urban Transformation and 12 cities under Smart Cities project would create necessary infrastructure that would facilitate economic growth she said.

Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) were the backbone of the economy, she said, adding 3.61 crore SMEs were accounting for 8 per cent of gross domestic product by giving employment to 80 million people.
title: “Despite global slump, Indian economy growing at 7 p.c.”
